item.title: Sentence Rearrangement
item.description:
Sentence Rearrangement: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ§©ðŸ”„

What is Sentence Rearrangement? ðŸ¤”

  • Rearranging a group of jumbled sentences into the correct, logical order.
  • Common in exams like SSC CHSL.
  • Tests your ability to understand sequence, logic, and flow in English passages. ðŸ“

Types of Sentence Rearrangement Questions ðŸ“š

  1. Basic Format
    • All statements are jumbled. Arrange them logically.
    • Example:
      • 1ï¸âƒ£ Rani fills the form to the dance show
      • 2ï¸âƒ£ A talent hunt show is looking for Classical dancers like Rani
      • 3ï¸âƒ£ Rani is called for auditions
      • 4ï¸âƒ£ Rani is a trained Bharatnatyam dancer
      • 5ï¸âƒ£ Rani gets selected
    • Correct Order: 4ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£3ï¸âƒ£5ï¸âƒ£
  2. Static First Statement
    • The first sentence is fixed; arrange the rest.
  3. Static Last Statement
    • The last sentence is fixed; arrange the others.
  4. Static First and Last Statement
    • Both first and last sentences are fixed; arrange sentences in between.

How to Solve Sentence Rearrangement Questions? ðŸ› ï¸

  • Read all statements carefully and find common points. ðŸ‘€
  • Look for connecting words like and, but, yet, when, then, they, anyway, etc. ðŸ”—
  • Spot patterns or sequences (chronological, cause-effect, etc.). ðŸ•°ï¸
  • Check for pronouns (he, she, it, they) and referencesâ€”these usually follow the noun they refer to. ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ¦°âž¡ï¸She
  • Start with the most general/introductory sentence and end with the conclusion or result. ðŸŽ¬
  • Once arranged, re-read the passage to ensure it makes sense. ðŸ”„

Tips & Tricks for Quick Solving âš¡

  • Paragraphs with a static statement are easierâ€”use the fixed point to anchor your logic. ðŸ
  • Strong vocabulary helps you understand sentence meanings and connections faster. ðŸ“–
  • Practice regularly to improve speed and accuracy! â±ï¸

Practice Questions with Answers & Emojis ðŸ“

  1. Our body takes in many toxins from
    • R) The atmosphere and the food
    • P) We eat, and we must have
    • Q) A process for purging these impurities.
    • Correct Order: RPQ
  2. In hatha yoga,
    • P) There are practices
    • R) To purify the stomach
    • Q) And the alimentary canal.
    • Correct Order: PRQ
  3. Calling for coordinated action between government and judiciary to reduce
    • Q) Pendency of commercial litigation, the Economic Survey said that
    • P) The initiative would help in improving ease of doing
    • R) Business (EODB) and boost economic activities.
    • Correct Order: QPR
  4. On the mental plane, worries, fears, anxieties
    • Q) And tensions that we experience in our daily life,
    • R) All create an accumulation
    • P) Of impurities in the subconscious mind.
    • Correct Order: QRP
  5. Private investment seems poised
    • R) To rebound with efforts being made for
    • Q) Expeditious resolution of bad loans and
    • P) Adequate recapitalisation of public sector banks (PSBs).
    • Correct Order: RQP

General Example with Step-by-Step Logic ðŸ§ 

Jumbled:

  1. Rani fills the form to the dance show
  2. A talent hunt show is looking for Classical dancers like Rani
  3. Rani is called for auditions
  4. Rani is a trained Bharatnatyam dancer
  5. Rani gets selected

Step-by-Step:

  • Start with introduction: 4 (Rani is a trained dancer)
  • What happens next? 2 (Show is looking for dancers)
  • Then: 1 (Rani fills form)
  • Next: 3 (She is called for auditions)
  • End: 5 (She gets selected)

Final Order: 4ï¸âƒ£2ï¸âƒ£1ï¸âƒ£3ï¸âƒ£5ï¸âƒ£

Summary Table ðŸ“Š

Step What to Do Emoji
Read All Understand every sentence ðŸ‘€
Find Links Spot connectors & references ðŸ”—
Use Patterns Look for sequence, cause-effect ðŸ•°ï¸
Anchor with Statics Use fixed first/last sentences ðŸ
Re-read Check logical flow ðŸ”„

Keep practicing these steps and use emojis to visualize the sequence! Sentence rearrangement will become easy and fun! ðŸ˜ƒðŸ§©

â‚

item.title: Idioms
item.description:
What Are Idioms and Phrases? ðŸ¤”

  • Idioms are expressions whose meanings are different from the literal meanings of the words.
    • Example: “Break the ice” means to start a conversation, not literally break ice! ðŸ§ŠðŸ—£ï¸
  • Phrases are groups of words that work together as a unit, often with a special meaning.

Why Are They Important? ðŸ†

  • Idioms and phrases are common in English exams (SSC, RRB, Bank, etc.).
  • Knowing them helps you score well and sound more natural in English! ðŸŽ¯

ðŸ“™ Idioms and Phrases

Idioms and Phrases form an important part of the English section of various competitive exams such as SSC exams, RRB exams, Bank exams and other Government exams. Candidates can easily fetch a good score in the English section if they are aware of important idioms and phrases, along with their meanings.

item.title: Pronouns
item.description:
Pronouns: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ“ðŸ¤—

What is a Pronoun? ðŸ¤”

  • A pronoun is a word used in place of a noun to avoid repetition or to point at something specific.
    • Example: Sarah has always loved fashion. She announced that she wants to go to fashion school. ðŸ‘§âž¡ï¸ðŸ‘©â€ðŸŽ“

Types of Pronouns & Examples with Emojis

1. Personal Pronouns ðŸ‘¤ðŸ‘¥

  • Refer to people or things.
  • Show point of view (person):
    • First person: I, we (speaker)
    • Second person: you (spoken to)
    • Third person: he, she, it, they (spoken about)
  • Subject/Object/Possessive forms:
Person Subject Object Possessive Adj. Possessive Pronoun
I I me my mine
We we us our ours
You you you your yours
He/She/It he/she/it him/her/it his/her/its his/hers/its
They they them their theirs 
- Example: **She** gave **him** her book. ðŸ“š

2. Possessive Pronouns ðŸ 

  • Show ownership.
    • my, our, your, her, its, their, his (adjectives)
    • mine, ours, yours, hers, its, theirs, his (pronouns)
  • Example: This is her pen. That house is ours. ðŸ–Šï¸ðŸ¡
  • Never use apostrophes: hers, theirs, ours.

3. Demonstrative Pronouns ðŸ‘‰

  • Point to things/people: this, these, that, those
    • This/these (near), that/those (far)
    • Example: These are my shoes. ðŸ‘Ÿ

4. Distributive Pronouns ðŸ”„

  • Refer to items one at a time: each, either, any, none, neither, every
    • Always singular; use singular verb.
    • Example: Each of us thinks the same. ðŸ¤

5. Reciprocal Pronouns ðŸ”

  • Show mutual action: each other (for two), one another (for more than two)
    • Example: They really love each other. â¤ï¸

6. Reflexive Pronouns ðŸªž

  • When subject and object are the same.
    • myself, yourself, ourselves, yourselves, himself, herself, itself, themselves
    • Example: I hurt myself. The boys hid themselves. ðŸ¤•

7. Emphatic (Emphasizing) Pronouns ðŸ’ª

  • Used for emphasis (can be removed without changing meaning).
    • myself, yourself, ourselves, himself, herself, itself, themselves
    • Example: You, yourself, are responsible for your problems. ðŸ˜¤

8. Indefinite Pronouns â“

  • Refer to non-specific people/things: everybody, nobody, little, no one, everything, nothing, all, somebody, anybody, someone, anyone, something, anything, some, any, both, another, much, few
    • Example: Someone ate my sandwich! ðŸ¥ª

9. Relative Pronouns ðŸ”—

  • Link clauses, give more info: who, which, that, whom, whose
    • Example: Have you seen those people who we met on holiday? ðŸ–ï¸

10. Interrogative Pronouns â“

  • Used to ask questions: who, which, whose, whom, what
    • Example: What do you want for dinner? ðŸ½ï¸

Key Rules & Tricks ðŸŽ¯

  • Personal pronouns: Choose subject/object form by removing the other noun and checking what sounds right.
    • Correct: She and I liked the book. ðŸ“–
    • Correct: The teacher gave chocolates to her and me. ðŸ«
  • Possessive pronouns: Never use apostrophes (hers, theirs, ours).
  • Distributive pronouns: Always singular verb.
    • Correct: Each of us thinks the same.
  • Reciprocal pronouns:
    • Each other for two, one another for more than two.
  • Reflexive vs. Emphatic:
    • Reflexive is essential (I hurt myself), emphatic is for stress (You, yourself, are responsible).
  • Relative pronouns:
    • Use who for people, which for things, that for people or things.

Common Errors & Corrections âŒâœ…

  1. Wrong: well appreciated by them who attended Correct: well appreciated by those who attended
  2. Wrong: pleura that cover the exterior Correct: pleura that covers the exterior
  3. Wrong: does not understand that how one can Correct: does not understand how one can
  4. Wrong: asked him that why he had not Correct: asked him why he had not
  5. Wrong: recognition of their efforts (for a man) Correct: recognition of his efforts
  6. Wrong: emptied of their tourists (for a place) Correct: emptied of its tourists
  7. Wrong: an advisory its issued Correct: an advisory it issued

Practice Questions with Answers ðŸ“

  • His speech was very thought provoking and well appreciated by them who attended…
    • Correct: by those who attended.
  • The pleura that cover the exterior part…
    • Correct: The pleura that covers the exterior part…
  • She does not understand that how one can…
    • Correct: She does not understand how one can…
  • Asked him that why he had not obtained…

item.title: Error Spotting
item.description:
Error Spotting: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸âœ…

What is Error Spotting? ðŸ¤”

  • Error spotting means finding grammar or usage mistakes in sentences.
  • Common in English exams like SSC CHSL.
  • With practice and some rules, you can master this section! ðŸ’ª

Top Tips for Error Spotting ðŸ“

  1. Some singular nouns are actually plural!
    • Words like: police, clergy, people, cattle.
    • âŒ People has left.
    • âœ… People have left. ðŸ‘¥
  2. Some nouns always take a plural verb.
    • Words like: clothes, scissors, trousers, spectacles.
    • âŒ The spectacles is missing.
    • âœ… The spectacles are missing. ðŸ‘“
  3. Measurement nouns stay singular after numbers (if followed by another noun).
    • âŒ This is a 9-meters scale.
    • âœ… This is a 9-meter scale. ðŸ“
  4. Keep pronouns consistent!
    • âŒ One must help his siblings.
    • âœ… One must help oneâ€™s siblings. ðŸ‘¤
  5. Use ‘whose’ for people, ‘which’ for things.
    • âŒ Which phone is kept on charging?
    • âœ… Whose phone is kept on charging? ðŸ“±
  6. â€˜Fewerâ€™ for number, â€˜lessâ€™ for quantity.
    • âŒ No less than thirty dogs were.
    • âœ… No fewer than thirty dogs were. ðŸ¶
  7. Question tags are always opposite in polarity.
    • âŒ Itâ€™s a bit early, is it?
    • âœ… Itâ€™s a bit early, isnâ€™t it? â°
  8. Use ’that’ after superlative adjectives, not ‘who’ or ‘which’.
    • âŒ These are the best which he could get.
    • âœ… These are the best that he could get. ðŸ¥‡
  9. ‘As’ is used before and after adjectives to show equality.
    • âŒ I can write as fast, if not faster than her.
    • âœ… I can write as fast as, if not faster than her. âœï¸
  10. â€˜Thoughâ€™ is followed by â€˜yetâ€™, not â€˜butâ€™.
    • âŒ Though he is rich but he is kind.
    • âœ… Though he is rich, yet he is kind. ðŸ’°
  11. Never use â€˜notâ€™ with â€˜unlessâ€™.
    • âŒ Unless you do not pay the fine, you will not be excused.
    • âœ… Unless you pay the fine, you will not be excused. ðŸ’µ
  12. â€˜Whileâ€™ for time duration, â€˜whenâ€™ for general sense.
    • âŒ When learning how to box, the technique is important.
    • âœ… While learning how to box, the technique is important. ðŸ¥Š

Smart Strategies for Error Spotting ðŸ§ 

  • Read the sentence carefully for meaning and structure.
  • Check each part independently if the error isnâ€™t obvious.
  • Eliminate wrong choices before selecting your answer.
  • Remember: The error is always underlined or highlighted.

Common Error Examples with Explanations ðŸ“

1. Singular/Plural & Determiners

  • âŒ Their was a place near the resort…
  • âœ… There was a place near the resort… ðŸ¨

2. Negative Sentences

  • âŒ Katherine did not want something to do with Richard…
  • âœ… Katherine did not want anything to do with Richard… ðŸš«

3. Quantifiers

  • âŒ The results werenâ€™t announced for much time…
  • âœ… The results werenâ€™t announced for some time… â³

4. Articles

  • âŒ A only reason Mario decided…
  • âœ… The only reason Mario decided… ðŸŽ¯

5. Countable/Uncountable

  • âŒ Much people decide to fast…
  • âœ… Many people decide to fast… ðŸ™

Quick Reference Table ðŸ“Š

Error Type Wrong Example Correct Example Emoji
Plural Noun People has left. People have left. ðŸ‘¥
Plural Form The spectacles is missing. The spectacles are missing. ðŸ‘“
Measurement 9-meters scale 9-meter scale ðŸ“
Pronoun Consistency One must help his siblings. One must help oneâ€™s siblings. ðŸ‘¤
Whose/Which Which phone is kept on charging? Whose phone is kept on charging? ðŸ“±
Fewer/Less No less than thirty dogs were. No fewer than thirty dogs were. ðŸ¶
Question Tag Itâ€™s a bit early, is it? Itâ€™s a bit early, isnâ€™t it? â°
Superlative/That The best which he could get. The best that he could get. ðŸ¥‡
As…As As fast, if not faster than her. As fast as, if not faster than her. âœï¸
Though/Yet Though he is rich but he is kind. Though he is rich, yet he is kind. ðŸ’°
Unless/Not Unless you do not pay the fine… Unless you pay the fine… ðŸ’µ
While/When When learning how to box… While learning how to box… ðŸ¥Š

How to Practice? ðŸ’¡

  • Read sentences and look for these common errors.
  • Try to spot which part is wrong and why.
  • Practice with real exam-style questions.

Keep practicing these rules and examples! Error spotting will become much easier! ðŸŒŸ 12

item.title: Fill in the blanks
item.description:
Fill in the Blanks: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis âœï¸ðŸ“

What is â€œFill in the Blanksâ€? ðŸ¤”

  • A question type where you choose the correct word(s) to complete a sentence.
  • Tests your vocabulary, grammar, idioms, phrases, and understanding of sentence structure. ðŸ“š

Important Topics to Revise ðŸ“–

  • Vocabulary: Know a wide range of words and their meanings. ðŸ“–
  • Idioms: Phrases with meanings different from their individual words. ðŸ—£ï¸
  • Phrases: Groups of words acting as a single unit. ðŸ§©
  • Clauses: Groups of words with a subject and predicate (often in complex sentences). ðŸ“
  • Grammar Concepts: Nouns, pronouns, tenses, prepositions, conjunctions, adjectives, subject-verb agreement, etc. ðŸ§ 

Top Tips for Solving Fill in the Blanks ðŸ†

  • Improve your vocabulary regularly. Learn new words every day! ðŸ“š
  • Read the question carefully. Thereâ€™s usually a clue in the sentence. ðŸ•µï¸â€â™‚ï¸
  • Look for grammar hints in the sentence (tense, subject-verb agreement, etc.). ðŸ“
  • Pay attention to idioms and phrases. Know their meanings and usage. ðŸ’¡
  • After choosing an option, read the sentence again to check if it makes sense. ðŸ”„
  • Manage your timeâ€”donâ€™t spend too long on one question! â°

Practice Examples with Explanations & Emojis

Single Word for Multiple Blanks ðŸ”¤

    • He was met by a _____ of noisy, angry youths.

  2. - You and all the others like you are ______.

    • The building has been lovingly ________.

    • The government _____ confidence in the housing market.

    • The debate has become ______ by conflicting ideological perspectives.

    • Grey clouds ______ the sun.
    • His origins and parentage are ______.
    • Answer: obscured (unclear, not known, not seen, uncertain) ðŸŒ«ï¸ðŸŒ¥ï¸
    • A good ______ walk is good for health.
    • She adopted a ______, businesslike tone.
    • The sea was shimmering and heaving beneath the ______ breeze.
    • The archers played a ______ part in the victory.

Pair of Words for Sentences ðŸ‘¬ 

  1. - It is shameful and horrifying and totally _____ and completely _____ that gender activists have failed to address this gaping inequality.
    • Answer: problematic, unacceptable (not satisfactory or allowable) ðŸš«
  2. - We still hear about the wage gap almost daily, and even though itâ€™s a myth, we _____ still marshal our resources to _____ this imaginary injustice.
    • Answer: should, rectify (should correct) âœ”ï¸
  3. - The burning of crop _____, which has been identified as the villain-in-chief of the current crisis, has _____ a large number of northern cities.
    • Answer: stubble, impacted (crop remains, affected) ðŸŒ¾ðŸ’¥
  4. - Facebook has said that the initiative, which could be _____ to other countries based on the response, is really aimed at protecting users by ensuring that nude photos and other _____ images of them donâ€™t get posted on Facebook, Instagram and other platforms without their consent.
    • Answer: extended, intimate (spread to, private images) ðŸŒðŸ”’
  5. - While India has never ______ that the Indian Ocean is â€“ Indiaâ€™s Ocean, China has _____ the bulk of the South China Sea as Chinaâ€™s Sea and even extended its claim to Indonesiaâ€™s shores.
    • Answer: claimed, claimed (asserted ownership) ðŸŒŠðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡³

Fill in the Blank with Two Possible Words ðŸ“ 

  1. - The theory of the objective correlative as it relates to literature was largely developed _____ the writings of the poet and literary critic T.S. Eliot.

  2. - Formalist followers _______ translated the fabula/syuzhet to the concept of story/plot.

  3. - The recording machinery was kept ______ screens.

  4. - History is not an _______ fact, but a reflection of certain attitudes, preconceptions, and injustices.

  5. - Soon we were driving ______ a narrow road.

Three Statements, One Word for All Blanks ðŸŽ¯ 

  1. - I stopped and listened, _______ my ears for any sound.

  2. - It is hard for logic to ______ over emotion.

  3. - She _______ her hand as if sheâ€™d been burnt.

item.title: Nouns
item.description:
Nouns: Easy Study Material with Emojis ðŸ“šðŸ˜ƒ

What is a Noun? ðŸ¤”

  • A noun is a word that names a person, place, thing, or idea.
    • Examples: Ram (person) ðŸ‘¦, Delhi (place) ðŸ™ï¸, dog (thing) ðŸ•, strength (idea) ðŸ’ª1.

Kinds of Nouns ðŸ·ï¸

  1. Proper Noun
    • Names a specific person or place.
    • Examples: Ram, Shyam, Delhi.
    • Tip: “Mango” is not a proper noun unless itâ€™s a specific type, like “Alphonso mango.” ðŸ¥­1
  2. Common Noun
    • Names any person or thing of the same kind.
    • Examples: boy, teacher, dog, shoe. ðŸ‘¦ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ«ðŸ•ðŸ‘Ÿ1
  3. Collective Noun
    • Names a group of people or things.
    • Examples: army, committee, crowd. ðŸª–ðŸ‘¥1
  4. Abstract Noun
    • Names an idea, quality, or stateâ€”not a physical object.
    • Examples: strength, innocence, fear, judgment. ðŸ’ªðŸ˜‡ðŸ˜±âš–ï¸1
  5. Material Noun
    • Names materials or substances.
    • Examples: cotton, gold, silver, protein. ðŸ§µðŸ¥‡1

Types of Nouns by Countability ðŸ”¢

  • Countable Nouns: Things you can count (book, apple, doctor, horse, kilogram).
    • Ask: â€œHow many?â€ ðŸ“šðŸðŸ‘¨â€âš•ï¸ðŸŽ
  • Uncountable Nouns: Things you canâ€™t count (milk, oil, sugar, gold, honesty).
    • Ask: â€œHow much?â€ ðŸ¥›ðŸ›¢ï¸ðŸ¯ðŸ¥‡1

Rules for Singular and Plural Nouns ðŸ“

Rule #1: Always Singular Nouns

  • Words like: scenery, advice, information, machinery, stationery, furniture, news, poetry, mathematics, ethics, innings, gallows.
  • Examples:
    • âœ… Mathematics is a difficult subject. ðŸ§®
    • âœ… The scenery of Kashmir is enchanting. ðŸžï¸
    • âŒ Advices are given… â†’ âœ… Advice is given…1

Rule #2: Plural in Meaning, Singular in Form

  • Words like: cattle, peasantry, clergy, gentry, artillery, company, vermin, people, police.
  • Examples:
    • âœ… The cattle are grazing in the ground. ðŸ„
    • âœ… The police have the situation under control. ðŸ‘®â€â™‚ï¸1

Rule #3: Always Plural Nouns

  • Words like: trousers, stockings, goods, scissors, shorts, alms, spectacles, measles, premises, thanks, tidings, annals.
  • Examples:
    • âœ… Where are my trousers? ðŸ‘–
    • âœ… Spectacles are costly items. ðŸ‘“1

Rule #4: Measurement Nouns Stay Singular After Numbers

  • Words: feet, score, year, meter, dozen, hundred, pair, head, rupee, million, litre, tola.
  • Examples:
    • âœ… A dozen people were killed. ðŸ‘¥
    • âœ… Two hundred rupee notes. ðŸ’µ
    • âœ… Two kilometre stretch of road. ðŸ›£ï¸1

Special Cases: Collective Nouns

  • Singular when acting as one unit:
    • The team has not arrived yet. ðŸ†
  • Plural when acting as individuals:
    • The jury were divided in their opinion. ðŸ‘©â€âš–ï¸ðŸ‘¨â€âš–ï¸1

Noun Phrases & Noun Clauses ðŸ“š

Common Errors & Corrections âŒâœ…

item.title: Verbs and Tense
item.description:
Verbs and Tenses: Easy Study Material with Emojis ðŸ˜ƒâ³

What is a Verb? ðŸ¤”

  • A verb is an action word that tells what the subject is doing.
    • Example: Maria sings. ðŸŽ¤
  • Every complete sentence needs a verb to make sense.
    • Example: Sing! (You is implied.) ðŸŽ¶

Key Parts of a Sentence ðŸ§©

  • Subject: The doer of the verb. ðŸ‘¤
  • Verb: The action or state. ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸
  • Object: The receiver of the action. ðŸŽ¯

Subject-Verb Agreement Rules ðŸ“

1. Singular Subject = Singular Verb / Plural Subject = Plural Verb

  • The dog is playing. ðŸ•
  • The dogs are playing. ðŸ•ðŸ•ðŸ•

2. â€˜Andâ€™ Joins Two Subjects = Plural Verb

  • My friend and his mother are in town. ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘¦

3. â€˜Andâ€™ Refers to Same Person/Thing = Singular Verb

  • The captain and coach has been sacked. (One person) ðŸ§‘â€âœˆï¸

4. Indefinite Pronouns (everyone, someone, nobody, etc.) = Always Singular

  • Everyone is selfish. ðŸ§‘

5. Percentages/Parts: Plural Meaning = Plural Verb

  • 40 out of 100 children are malnourished. ðŸ‘§ðŸ‘¦

6. â€˜Either/Orâ€™ or â€˜Neither/Norâ€™: Verb Agrees with Nearest Subject

  • Neither you nor your dogs know how to behave. ðŸ¶
  • Either you or I am at fault. ðŸ‘¤

7. â€˜Eitherâ€™/â€˜Neitherâ€™ as Pronouns = Singular Verb

  • Either of the books is fine. ðŸ“š

8. Connectives (along with, as well as, together with): Verb Matches First Subject

  • Mr. Ram, accompanied by his wife, was banished. ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ¦±ðŸ‘©

9. â€˜A number ofâ€™ = Plural Verb / â€˜The number ofâ€™ = Singular Verb

  • A number of students are going. ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸŽ“
  • The number of questions is 25. 2ï¸âƒ£5ï¸âƒ£

10. Units of Measurement/Time = Singular Verb

  • Five gallons of oil was required. ðŸ›¢ï¸

11. â€˜Few, Many, Several, Both, All, Someâ€™ + Countable Noun = Plural Verb

  • Some men are needed. ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ”§

12. â€˜Few, Many, Several, Both, All, Someâ€™ + Uncountable Noun = Singular Verb

  • Some data was stolen. ðŸ’»

Practice Questions with Answers & Emojis ðŸ“

  1. Critics allege that the government is trying to leverage last yearâ€™s disaster and use the funds they collected for reconstruction…
    • Tip: Use â€˜forâ€™ with nouns like â€˜reconstructionâ€™. ðŸ—ï¸
  2. Some of these dams are witnessing record low levels…
    • Use present continuous for ongoing actions. ðŸ’§
  3. …what the surveillance cameras may have recorded in or near Epsteinâ€™s cell.
    • Use past participle â€˜recordedâ€™ with â€˜haveâ€™. ðŸ“¹
  4. …says his countries will not be able to hold up its side of an immigration agreement…
    • Use the idiom â€˜hold upâ€™ for â€˜withstandâ€™. ðŸ¤
  5. It looks like the Supreme Court will score a goal for women…
    • Use â€˜willâ€™ for present/future, not â€˜hadâ€™. âš½
  6. The cat looked desperate to get inside…
    • Use â€˜toâ€™ + base verb (to get). ðŸˆ
  7. Social justice deals with various aspects…
    • Use present tense if the sentence is about a current fact. âš–ï¸
  8. …most of the scientific advances believed to have been made in Europe…
    • Use past tense â€˜believedâ€™ for past context. ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ”¬
  9. The state’s new policy on tourism is supposed to give investors a big advantage.
    • Correct verb form: â€˜is supposed toâ€™. ðŸ¨
  10. She let the student who caused the accident off the hook.
    • Correct relative pronoun and verb tense. ðŸš—

Quick Tips for Verbs & Tenses ðŸ’¡

  • Always check if the subject and verb agree in number!
  • Watch for common connectors and pronouns that affect verb choice.
  • Use present continuous (â€˜is/are + -ingâ€™) for ongoing actions.
  • Use the correct tense for the context (present, past, future).
  • For measurement, time, and collective nouns, check if the group acts as one or many.

Practice these rules and examples with emojis for easy recall and exam success! ðŸ˜ƒðŸ“–

item.title: Sentence Correction
item.description:
Sentence Correction: Study Material with Emojis ðŸ“âœ¨

Key Rules for Sentence Correction ðŸŽ¯

Rule #1: No Article with â€œKind of/Sort of/Type ofâ€ ðŸš«ðŸ“–

  • Donâ€™t use â€œa/an/theâ€ with â€œkind of,â€ â€œsort of,â€ â€œtype of,â€ etc.
    • âŒ What type of the books you like to read?
    • âœ… What type of books you like to read?
    • âŒ What sort of an insect is that?
    • âœ… What sort of insect is that?

Rule #2: â€œEach of/One of/None ofâ€ + Plural Noun ðŸ‘¥

  • Always use a plural noun after â€œeach of,â€ â€œone of,â€ â€œnone of.â€
    • âŒ Each of the player performed well.
    • âœ… Each of the players performed well.
    • âŒ None of the student scored above 90%.
    • âœ… None of the students scored above 90%.

Rule #3: Collective Noun + Plural Verb When Not a Single Unit ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ‘§â€ðŸ‘¦

  • Use a plural verb if the collective noun isnâ€™t acting as one unit.
    • âŒ The resources was divided based on its expertise.
    • âœ… The resources were divided based on their expertise.

Rule #4: Present Continuous for Problematic Recurring Actions ðŸ”

  • Use present continuous (is/are + -ing) for actions that happen repeatedly and are problematic.
    • âŒ She always hits me without any reason.
    • âœ… She is always hitting me without any reason.

Rule #5: Future Conditionals â€“ Present for â€œIf/Whenâ€, Future for Result â³

  • For two future actions, use simple present for the condition, simple future for the result.
    • âŒ The moment she will enter the room, we will start singing.
    • âœ… The moment she enters the room, we will start singing.

Rule #6: Impossible Past Condition â€“ Had + Would Have + V3 âª

  • For impossible past conditions, use â€œhadâ€ for the condition and â€œwould have + V3â€ for the result.
    • âŒ If Jacob would have called me, I would have picked him up.
    • âœ… If Jacob had called me, I would have picked him up.

Practice Questions with Answers & Emojis

  1. The employees of this company demand higher salaries for a very long period of time.
    • âœ… The employees of this company have been demanding higher salaries for a very long time. ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ’¼ðŸ’¸
  2. The train is expected to arrive between 11 pm to 12 pm.
    • âœ… The train is expected to arrive between 11pm and 12pm. ðŸš†
  3. If the cab would have started on time, she would have reached office on time.
    • âœ… If the cab had started on time, she would have reached office on time. ðŸš•
  4. The renowned Birlaâ€™s family is divided on the property.
    • âœ… The renowned Birlaâ€™s family are divided on the property. ðŸ‘ª
  5. What kind of a car do you want?
    • âœ… What kind of car do you want? ðŸš—
  6. Nishi said to the boy, “Can you take me home now?â€
    • âœ… Nishi asked the boy if he could take her home then. ðŸ 
  7. A loud, harsh, piercing cry.
    • âœ… Screech ðŸ¦…
  8. The payment was collected by the hardworking salesman.
    • âœ… The hardworking salesman collected the payment. ðŸ’°
  9. Though very old, yet my grandfather is the complete head of the extended family.
    • âœ… Undisputed ðŸ‘´ðŸ 
  10. Back to the drawing board.
    • âœ… An idea has been unsuccessful and a new one must be devised. ðŸ”„ðŸ“
  11. If the screen of the computer (was bright enough), it would have been easier to read from here.
    • âœ… had been brighter ðŸ’»
  12. By the time she reached there, he left the place.
    • âœ… By the time she reached there, he had left the place. ðŸ•’
  13. This kingdom has been belonging to us since generations.
    • âœ… has belonged ðŸ‘‘
  14. Rama told his wife, he would not mind standing and eat the dinner.
    • âœ… standing and eating the dinner ðŸ½ï¸
  15. People in villages do not have enough water, besides many people in metro cities have water even for their swimming pools.
    • âœ… whereas ðŸŒŠðŸŠ

Tips for Sentence Correction Success ðŸ’¡

  • Always check for articles, verb forms, and noun agreement.
  • Watch for tricky conditionals and tense usage.
  • Use present continuous for repeated, problematic actions.
  • For collective nouns, decide if the group acts as one (singular) or individuals (plural).
  • Read the sentence aloud to check what â€œsounds right.â€

Keep practicing these rules and examples with emojis for quick recall and easy understanding! ðŸ˜ƒðŸ“–

item.title: Active Passive voice
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

ðŸ“™ ACTIVE AND PASSIVE VOICE

What is Voice of a verbâ”

The voice of a verb expresses whether the subject in the sentence has performed or received the action.

For example:

  • The watchman opens the door.
  • The door is opened by the watchman.
Active Voice

In the active voice, the subject of the sentence performs the action expressed by the verb. The structure of an active voice sentence is typically: Â 

â„¹ï¸ Subject + Verb + Object Â 
Here are some examples
  • The dog (subject) chased (verb) the ball (object).
  • She (subject) wrote (verb) a letter (object).
  • The wind (subject) blew (verb) the leaves (object).
Passive Voice

When the action expressed by the verb is received by the subject, it is passive voice. Passive voice is used when the doer of the action is not known and the focus of the sentence is on the action and not the subject.

For example
  • Eggs are laid by hens.
  • Nests are built by birds.

Active and Passive Voice Rules for Conversion of Sentence

Below are the active-passive voice rules to follow for changing an active sentence into a passive voice. Before heading to the rules of active-passive voice, letâ€™s check the examples of active and passive voice sentences.

Conversion of Active and Passive voice examples ðŸ‘€

  • Active voice - Rita wrote a letter. (Subject + Verb + Object)
  • Passive voice - A letter was written by Rita. (Object) + (auxiliary verb) + (past participle) + (by subject).
  • Active voice - She cooks food. (Subject + Verb + Object)
  • Passive voice - The food is cooked by her. (Object) + (auxiliary verb) + (past participle) + (by subject)

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #1

âž¡ï¸ Identify the (S+V+O) Subject, Verb and object in the active sentence to convert to passive voice.

Example: He drives car. (Subject â€“ He, verb â€“ Drives, object â€“ Car)

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #2

âž¡ï¸ Interchange the object and subject with each other, i.e., object of the active sentence become the subject of the passive sentence.

Example

Active voice - She knits sweater. (Subject â€“ She, Verb â€“ Knits, Object â€“ Sweater). Passive voice - The sweater is knitted by her. (Object sweater is interchanged with the subject She).

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #3

âž¡ï¸ In passive voice sometimes the subject is not used, i.e., the subject in passive voice can be omitted if the sentence without it gives enough meaning.

Example: Milk is sold in litres

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #4

âž¡ï¸ Change the base verb in the active sentence into the past participle i.e., third form verb in a passive sentence i.e., preceded by (By, With, to, etc). Base verbs are never used in passive voice sentences.

Examples

  • Active voice - She prepares dinner.
  • Passive voice - The dinner is prepared by her.
  • Active voice - She knows him.
  • Passive voice - He is known to her
  • Active voice - Juice fills the jar.
  • Passive voice - The jar is filled with juice.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #5

âž¡ï¸ While conversion of Active voice sentence to Passive voice sentence, the pronoun used in the sentence also changes in the following manner.

Active Voice Pronoun Passive Voice Pronoun
I Me
We Us
He Him
She Her
They Them
You You
It It

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule #6

âž¡ï¸ Use the suitable helping or auxiliary verb (is/am/are/was, etc.). The rules for using auxiliary verbs in passive voice sentences are different for each tense.

For example

  • The letter is written by her.
  • A book was not bought by her
  • Chocolates are being eaten by them.

Forms of Active and Passive Voice for All Tenses

Simple Present Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
He writes an essay An essay is written by him
Sheena does the housework The housework is done by Sheena
She cares for the rabbit The rabbit is being cared for by her
Jacob always plays the guitar The guitar is always played by Jacob

Present Continuous Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
They are eating bananas The bananas are being eaten by them
Bob is drawing a diagram A diagram is being drawn by Bob
Samta is playing the piano A piano is being played by Samta
She is waiting for Reema Reema is being waited for by her

Present Perfect Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
Has he done the work? Has the work been done by him?
Have they left the apartment? Has the apartment been left by them?
He created this masterpiece This masterpiece is created by him
He read the newspaper The newspaper is being read by him
âš ï¸
Except certain exemptions, no passive Voice formation for the following tenses can be formed - Present Perfect Continuous Tense, Past Perfect Continuous Tense, Future Perfect Continuous Tense and Future Continuous Tense.

Simple Past Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
Ria paid the bills The bills were paid by Ria
The teacher called the student The student was called by the teacher
She did not buy the fruits The fruits were not bought by her

Past Continous Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
They were waiting for him He was being waited for by them
Astha was learning French French was being learnt by Astha
She was playing kabaddi Kabaddi was being played by her

Past Perfect Tense

Active Sentences **Passive Sentences
She won the match The match had been won by her
I had finished her work Her work had been finished by me
He had missed the last metro The last metro had been missed by him

Simple Future Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
He will write a letter A letter will be written by him
He will repair her cycle Her cycle will be repaired by him
He shall start the meeting The meeting will be started by him

Future Perfect Tense

Active Sentences Passive Sentences
Meena will not have changed the bedsheet The bed sheet will not have been changed by Meena
They will have won the match The match will have been won by them
Reena will have washed the skirt The skirt will have been washed by Reena

Practice Questions ðŸ§ 

Directions: ðŸ’¡ In the following questions, a sentence has been given in either Active or Passive Voice.From the four options select the one which best expresses the same sentence in the opposite voice than mentioned in the question.

  1. Never disobey your elders. â“

    1. You are asked not to disobey your elders.
    2. You are ordered not to disobey your elders.
    3. Do not disobey your elders.
    4. You are not to disobey your elders.

Answer: âœ… 1. You are asked not to disobey your elders.

  1. The students were listening to the teacher â“

    1. The teacher is listened to by the students
    2. The teacher listened to students.
    3. The teacher was listening to by the students
    4. The teacher was listened to by the students.

Answer: âœ… 4. The teacher was listened to by the students.

  1. I have to do it. â“
  1. It is be done by me
  2. It should to be done by me
  3. It has to be done by me.
  4. It would to be done by me.

Answer: âœ… 3. It has to be done by me.

  1. Tell the maid to prepare tea. â“

    1. You are ordered to tell the maid to prepare tea.
    2. You are said to tell the maid to prepare tea.
    3. You are advised to tell the maid to prepare tea.
    4. You are asked to tell the maid to prepare tea.

Answer: âœ… 4. You are asked to tell the maid to prepare tea.

  1. Who stole your bike â“

    1. Your bike was stolen by him?
    2. By whom was your bike stolen?
    3. Your bike was stolen by whom?
    4. By whom your bike stolen?

Answer: âœ… 2. By whom was your bike stolen?

item.title: Adjectives
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

ðŸ“™ ADJECTIVES - DEGREES OF COMPARISON & EXCEPTIONS

Adjectives

*ï¸âƒ£ The simplest way to explain adjectives is that they describe a noun.

*ï¸âƒ£ It gives us a better idea of the noun, by telling us its size, shape, age, colour, or other quality. Example: That is a big tree.

How to order adjectives in English

If a sentence has more than one adjective, they are arranged by priority, wherein the adjectives that actively describe the noun come before the more neutral nouns.

  1. Quantity or number
  2. Quality or opinion
  3. Size
  4. Age
  5. Shape
  6. Color
  7. Proper Adjective (often nationality, other place of origin, or material)
  8. Purpose or qualifier

Example: I love that big, old, green, antique car that is parked at the end of the street.

Big describes the size of the car. Since, size is number 3 in the list, it comes before number (4) age (old) and (6) colour (green).

Degrees of Adjectives

There are three degrees of adjectives.

  1. Positive Adjective
  2. Comparative Adjective
  3. Superlative Adjective

Positive Degree

Tom is tall a boy.

  • In this sentence the word â€˜tallâ€™ is an adjective telling us how Tom is.
  • There is no other person or thing in this sentence used to compare Tom with, but it is the general way of saying about persons, animals and things that they have some quality (here â€˜tallnessâ€™) above average in general sense.
  • The adjective word â€˜tallâ€™ is said to be in the â€œpositive formâ€.
  • This comparison is called â€œpositive degreeâ€ comparison.

Comparatives

  • 1ï¸âƒ£ One way to describe nouns (people, objects, animals, etc.) is by comparing them to something else.
  • âž¡ï¸ When comparing two things, youâ€™re likely to use adjectives like smaller, bigger, taller, more interesting, and less expensive.
  • ðŸ”” Notice the â€‘er ending, and the words more and less.

See the sentences below for an illustration of this common error: ðŸ‘€

Correct Use âœ… His cat is larger than my dog.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« His cat is more larger than my dog.

So, what makes the first example wrong and the second right? There are a few rules that ex- plain this:

  • For adjectives that are just one syllable, add -er to the end (this explains the above example).
  • For two-syllable adjectives not ending in -y and for all three-or-more-syllable adjectives, use the form â€œmore + adjective.â€
  • For two-syllable adjectives ending in -y, change the -y to -i and add -er.

ðŸ‘‰ These simple rules make it easy to tell when you should add -er or -ier and when you should use â€œmore + adjective.â€

Examples:
Correct Use âœ… This house is more exciting than ever
Incorrect Use ðŸš« This house is excitinger than ever.
Correct Use âœ… Mike is funnier than Isaac.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Mike is more funny than Isaac.

Tip

Notice the spelling change for adjectives ending in â€‘y: the comparative ends in â€‘ier.

Correct Use âœ… This book is more boring than the last one.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« This book is boringer than the last one
Correct Use âœ… Advertising pressures women to be thinner.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Advertising pressures women to be more thin.

Superlatives

  • When comparing more than two things, youâ€™ll likely use words and phrases like smallest, biggest, tallest, most interesting, and least interesting.
  • Notice the â€‘est ending and the words most and least.
  • Make sure you use the proper ending or superlative adjective when forming these superlatives
Examples:
no. The examples below illustrate the correct form: â¤µï¸
1 Martha is the elder of the four sisters.
2 If there were only two sisters, we could use the comparative elder here. Because there are four sisters, we need a superlative.
3 Martha is the eldest of the four sisters.
4 I think his last book is his least interesting; his third book was the most interesting.
5 That must be the weirdest play ever written.
  • Remember that adjectives ending in â€‘y change their spelling when â€‘est is added.
  • To form these superlatives, change the y to an i before adding the -est ending, as illustrated below:
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Correct Use âœ…
That is the sleepyest puppy of the litter. That is the sleepiest puppy of the litter.
Forming Comparative and Superlatives of Irregular Adjectives

*ï¸âƒ£ Itâ€™s important to note that there are irregular adjectives (and adverbs) that you have to memorize because they donâ€™t follow the rules above. They are:

Adjective/Adverb Comparative Superlative
good/well better best
bad/badly worse worst
far farther, further the farthest, the furthest
little less least
Examples:
no. Irregular words as comparatives and superlatives: â¤µï¸
1 Today I had the best time touring the city.
2 I went farther than my friend when we walked around the park.
3 You dance better than I do.
4 You bought the least attractive pair of moccasins at the thrift store.
5 He can run the farthest of his classmates, but thatâ€™s only once around the track.
6 I do badly in math, but at least Iâ€™m not the worst.
Comparative and Superlative of â€œHandsomeâ€

Besides the irregular words in the table above, one other unclear comparative/superlative choice is:

  • Handsomer.
  • More handsome.
  • Handsomest/most handsome.

The rules call for handsomer and handsomest, but usage has changed over time.

Modern speakers prefer more handsome to handsomer, and there is an even split between handsomest and most handsome.

Preferred usage typically follows what native speakers say, and the trend seems to be moving toward the simpler construction of more + adjective and the most + adjective.

Parallel Degree: This comparison is used to show that the qualities of two items (adjectives or adverbs) talked about in the given sentence go parallel.

If one quality (adjective or adverb) increases, the other quality (adjective or adverb) increases, and if one quality decreases, the other quality also decreases.

Eg: The bigger the box, the heavier it is.

Forming Comparative and Superlatives of Various Adjectives
Positive Comparative Superlative
Big Bigger Biggest
Great Greater Greatest
Short Shorter Shortest
Old Older Oldest
Large Larger Largest
Happy Happier Happiest
Lucky Luckier Luckiest
Heavy Heavier Heaviest
Beautiful More beautiful Most beautiful
Horrible More horrible Most horrible
Good Better Best
Bad Worse Worst
Little Less Least
Far Farther Farthest

Rules for Degrees of Comparisons

Rule #1

While making comparisons between two things the comparative degree is used and not the superlative degree.

Example

Incorrect Use ðŸš« Correct Use âœ…
He is the richest of the two brothers. He is the richer of the two brothers.

As we can see in the examples, comparison is between two brothers thus comparative degree will be used.

Rich Richer Richest

Rule #2

  • If a choice has to be made between two persons or things the comparative degree will be used.
  • Article â€˜theâ€™ will be used before the comparative degree and (of the) will be used after the comparative degree.
The structure will be……the + Comparative + of the……
Example
  • Lucknow is the better of the two cities.
  • MS Dhoni is the better of the two players

Similarly, if the choice is to be made between more than two things or persons the superlative degree will be used.

The structure will be……the + Superlative degree + of the……
Example
  • Rahul is the best of all the batsmen in the Indian cricket team.
  • English is the easiest of all the languages taught in the school.

Rule #3

If an adjective is to be used between â€œasâ€¦â€¦â€¦asâ€ and â€œsoâ€¦â€¦.asâ€ the adjective should be in positive degree.

Example
  • Asâ€¦..as is used to show that something is equally good or bad.
  • Hisar is as hot as Ganganagar in May.
Example
  • Soâ€¦â€¦.as is used to show something is not as good or as bad.
  • Even with the aggressive marketing campaign, the response is not so good.
Example
  • This rule is also applicable in adverbs.
  • Geeta danced as gracefully as Anita.

Rule #4

*ï¸âƒ£ If two qualities are to be compared of the same person or thing then we donâ€™t use the comparative degree.

*ï¸âƒ£ Comparative degree is used for comparison between two different things or persons.

*ï¸âƒ£ Instead of using the comparative degree â€˜moreâ€™, positive degree will be used.

Example - English needs more practice than other languages.

Rule #5

ðŸ‘‰ In comparative degree â€˜thanâ€™ is used. But for adjectives ending in â€˜iorâ€™ â€˜thanâ€™ is not used, instead â€˜toâ€™ is used.

ðŸ‘‰ List of such adjectives is Superior, inferior, junior, senior, prior, anterior, posterior, exterior, interior etc.

Example
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Correct Use âœ…
He was junior than me in college. He was junior to me in college.

Rule #6

ðŸ‘‰ If two adjectives are being used for the same noun or pronoun then the adjective should be in the same degree.

Example
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Correct Use âœ…
India is the greatest and tolerant country. India is a great and tolerant country.

Practice Questions ðŸ§ 

Directions: ðŸ’¡ In the following question, one part of the sentence may have an error. Find out which part of the sentence has an error and select the option corresponding to it. If the sentence is free from error, select the ‘No error’ option.

Question 1

Gone are the days when nuclear weapons (A)/ were the only threat; humans have designed (B)/ far worst weapons now. (C)/ No error (D)

  1. A
  2. B
  3. C
  4. D

Correct Option: 3

Solution:

  • The third part of the sentence is incorrect therefore; the right answer is option 3.

  • The third part of the sentence is wrong because of the use of the adjective â€˜worstâ€™. The sentence is comparing a present day situation with the past so the adjective used should be of a comparative degree instead of a superlative degree.

  • â€˜Worstâ€™ is used to describe something that is beyond bad, eg., â€˜This is the worst meal I have ever had in my life.â€™

  • Since the sentence calls for a comparative degree of the adjective â€˜badâ€™, â€˜worseâ€™ should be used instead of â€˜worstâ€™.

  • âœ… Correct sentence: â€˜Gone are the days when nuclear weapons were the only threat; humans have designed far worse weapons now.â€™

Question 2

Rohan has a (A)/ most unique collection (B)/ of wrist watches. (C)/ No error (D)

  1. A
  2. B
  3. C
  4. D

Correct Option: 2

Solution:

  • Words like unique, major, minor, maximum, minimum, full, complete, perfect, round, etc. are already in their superlative form.
  • So, they do not take any comparative or superlative degree of adjective.
  • Thus, remove most from the sentence.
  • âœ… Correct Sentence: â€œRohan has a unique collection of wrist watches.â€

Question 3

As soon as I entered the room (A)/ a black long snake hurled (B)/ into the bed sheet. (C)/ No error (D)

  1. A
  2. B
  3. C
  4. D

Correct Option: 2

Solution:

  • Here, concept of adjective is brought under consideration.
  • When adjectives of colour and size are used together in a sentence, then, following pattern is considered: - adjective of size -> adjective of colour.
  • Thus, replace black long with long black.
  • âœ… Correct Sentence: â€œAs soon as I entered the room, a black long snake hurled into the bed sheet.â€

Directions: ðŸ’¡ Improve the bracketed part of the sentence. Four alternatives are given to the underlined part which will improve the meaning of the sentence. Choose the correct alternative and select the option corresponding to it. In case no improvement is needed, select the option corresponding to ‘No improvement’.

Question 4

Bill Gates is once again (the rich person) in the world.

  1. The richer person
  2. The most richer person
  3. The richest person
  4. No improvement

Correct Option: 3

Solution:

  • The sentence uses an incorrect form of adjective â€˜richâ€™.
  • The correct form must be a superlative adjective i.e., â€˜richestâ€™.
  • âœ… Correct Sentence: â€œBill Gates is once again the richest person in the world.â€

Question 5

Raghu is a (coward) man who never takes any decision on his own.

  1. cowardly man
  2. coward men
  3. cowardly woman
  4. No improvement

Correct option: 1

Solution:

  • Here, concept of adjective is brought under consideration.
  • “Coward” is a noun and “man” is a noun. Hence, replace it with adjective cowardly.
  • âœ… Correct sentence: â€œRaghu is a cowardly man who never takes any decision on his own.â€

Question 6

The higher the demand, (the more) the prices.

  1. great
  2. the greater
  3. high
  4. No improvement

Correct Option: 2

Solution:

  • Clearly, comparative degree of adjective should be used.
  • Since, ‘higher’ is given. So, to connect with it, similar type of degree should be used.
  • âœ… Correct Sentence: â€œThe higher the demand, the greater the prices.â€

Question 7

The 4th day of admissions at the University started (with most students) cancelling their admissions as compared to new enrollments.

  1. with many students
  2. with more students
  3. with all students
  4. No improvement

Correct Option: 2

Solution:

  • The sentence is compares enrolments and cancellations (…as compared to…) in the admission process which has already started and is still going on.
  • Here, two things are compared hence comparative adjective â€˜more thanâ€™ will be used.
  • In the above example superlative degree is used (most) which is wrong as it is used when a particular thing is compared with a group (or class) of things.
  • For eg: It rained the most in July as compared to other months.
  • In option 1, â€˜manyâ€™ is just a simple numeral adjective and not comparing two things, hence, it will make a wrong sentence.
  • Option 3, is also wrong as â€˜allâ€™ is the wrong adjective.
  • âœ… Correct sentence: â€œThe 4th day of admissions at the University started with more students cancelling their admissions as compared to new enrolments.â€
Directions: ðŸ’¡ Read the following sentence and choose the degree of the underlined adjective.

Question 8

Dhiraj claimed, “I am the funniest out of all the comedians.”

  1. Positive
  1. Comparative
  2. Superlative
  3. None of these

Correct Option: 3

Solution:

  • A positive adjective is used in order to describe. For example: â€œThis is good soupâ€ and â€œI am funny.â€
  • A comparative adjective is used to compare two things (and is often followed by the word than). For example: â€œThis soup is better than that saladâ€ or â€œI am funnier than her.â€
  • A superlative adjective is used to compare three or more things. For example: â€œThis is the best soup in the whole worldâ€ or â€œI am the funniest out of all the other bloggers.

item.title: Adverbs
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

ðŸ“™ Rules for Adverbs

What do Adverbs modify â”

An adverb is a word that modifies or describes:
- A verb ðŸŸ° he sings louadly
- An adjective ðŸŸ° he sings louadly
- Another adverb ðŸŸ° he sings louadly
- Or even a whole sentence ðŸŸ° he sings louadly

*ï¸âƒ£ Adverbs often end in -ly, but some look exactly the same as their adjective counterparts. Take for example, fast, quick, bad, good, and so on.

Examples
  1. Tom Longboat did not run badly.
  2. Tom is very tall.
  3. The race finished too quickly

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 1

ðŸ‘‰ Many adverbs end in -ly, but many do not. Generally, if a word can have -ly added to its adjective form, place it there to form an adverb.

Examples
  1. She thinks quick/quickly. => How does she think? Quickly.
  2. She is a quick/quickly thinker. => Quick is an adjective describing thinker, so no -ly is attached.
  3. She thinks fast/fastly. => Fast answers the question how, so it is an adverb. But fast never has -ly attached to it

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 2

ðŸ‘‰ Adverbs that answer the question â€˜howâ€™ sometimes cause grammatical problems. It can be a challenge to determine if -ly should be attached.

ðŸ«· Avoid the trap of -ly with linking verbs such as taste, smell, look, feel, which pertain to the senses. Adverbs are often misplaced in such sentences, which require adjectives instead.

Examples:
  1. Roses smell sweet/sweetly => In this case, smell is a linking verbâ€”which requires an adjective to modify rosesâ€”so no -ly
  2. The woman looked angry/angrily to us => Did the woman look with her eyes, or are we describing her appearance? We are describing her appearance (she appeared angry), so no -ly
  3. The woman looked angry/angrily at the paint splotches. => Here the woman actively looked (used her eyes), so the -ly is added.
  4. She feels bad/badly about the news. => She is not feeling with fingers, so no -ly

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 3

ðŸ‘‰ The word good is an adjective, whose adverb equivalent is well.

Examples:
  1. You did a good job. => Good describes the job.
  2. You smell good today. => Good describes your fragrance, not how you smell with your nose, so using the adjective is correct.
  3. You smell well for someone with a cold. => You are actively smelling with your nose here, so use the adverb.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 4

ðŸ‘‰ The word well can be an adjective, too. When referring to health, we often use well rather than good.

Examples:
  1. You do not look well today.
  2. I donâ€™t feel well, either.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 5

ðŸ‘‰ Adjectives come in three forms, also called degrees. An adjective in its normal or usual form is called a positive degree adjective. A common error in using adjectives and adverbs arises from using the wrong form of comparison.

Examples:
  1. She is the cleverer of the two women (never cleverest).

Point to Remember

The word cleverest is what is called the superlative form of clever. Use it only when comparing three or more things. For example - She is the cleverest of them all.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Chocolate or vanilla: which do you like best?
Correct Use âœ… Chocolate or vanilla: which do you like better?

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 6

ðŸ‘‰ There are also three degrees of adverbs. In formal usage, do not drop the -ly from an adverb when using the comparative form.

Examples:
Incorrect Use ðŸš« Talk quieter.
Correct Use âœ… Talk more quietly.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« She spoke quicker than he did.
Correct Use âœ… She spoke more quickly than he did.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 7

ðŸ‘‰ When this, that, these, and those are followed by a noun, they are adjectives. When they appear without a noun following them, they are pronouns.

Examples:
  1. This house is for sale. => This is an adjective and a pronoun as well.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 8

ðŸ‘‰ Use of â€˜Muchâ€™ and â€˜Veryâ€™ - â€˜Muchâ€™ qualifies adjectives or adverbs in the comparative degree; â€˜ veryâ€™ in the positive.

Examples:
  1. The air is much hotter today than yesterday.
  2. This book is much heavier than that.
  3. This book is very useful.
  4. He spoke very loudly.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 9

ðŸ‘‰ Use of hard, hardly, scarce, scarcely.

Examples:
  1. Hard â€“ as an adverb means â€˜Diligentlyâ€™. It usually follows the verb. For example,
    • He works hard to make both ends meet.
    • Our team played hard in Pakistan.
    • I tried hard to succeed.
  2. Hardly - When used as an adverb means scarcely, barely. It conveys a negative meaning/ Hardly and scarcely are followed by when. For example,
    • Hardly (Scarcely) had he reached the station, when the train left.
  3. Scarce - As an adjective means â€˜not plentiful, hard to find, not often found. For example,
    • Coal has become scarce in England.
  4. Scarcely â€“ as an adverb is almost synonymous to â€˜Hardlyâ€™. For example,
    • I can scarcely hear you.
    • They have scarcely enough to look after their children

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 10

ðŸ‘‰ Adverb â€˜Asâ€™ is used with the following verbs - Regard, Describe, define, treat, view, know.

ðŸ‘‰ Adverb â€˜Asâ€™ is not used with the following verbs - Name, elect, think, consider, call, appoint, make, choose.

Examples:
  1. I regard him as my mentor.
  2. Biology is defined as the study of organisms.

#ï¸âƒ£ Rule # 11

ðŸ‘‰ Elseâ€™ should be followed by â€˜butâ€™

Examples
Incorrect Use ðŸš« It is nothing else than pride.
Correct Use âœ… It is nothing else but pride.
Incorrect Use ðŸš« You do nothing else except feel sorry for yourself.
Correct Use âœ… You do nothing else but feel sorry for yourself.

item.title: Articles
item.description:
Articles are a part of determiners that are used before nouns to define nouns or give some information about nouns.

Articles are of three types: A, An and The

ðŸ“™ Article - A/An

  • ðŸ‘‰ These two articles are basically used to show the number â€˜oneâ€™ of something like a chair, an apple, etc.
  • ðŸ‘‰ If we have a class of something and we have to choose or pick one/any/each/every from that particular class, we use Article A/An.
  • ðŸ‘‰ For example, An apple a day keeps the doctor away. In this sentence an apple â€˜refers to any apple and â€˜a dayâ€™ refers to every day.
  • ðŸ‘‰ If I say â€˜a studentâ€™, I am not referring to any particular student but I am referring to any student from the class â€˜studentâ€™.
  • ðŸ‘‰ â€˜Aâ€™ is used before the consonant sounds and â€˜Anâ€™ is used before the vowel sounds. Eg: a boy, a student, an M.P., an honest man, etc.

Note: Usage of A/An has nothing to do with letters of English language. These are used according to the sound with which a word starts.

Rules:

  1. A/An is used before singular countable nouns. For example,

    • Twelve inches make a foot.

  2. Before a person not known to the speaker. For example,

    • A Mr. Sharma has come to meet you.

  3. Before the verbs used as a noun. For example,

    • Have a bath, take a ride, take a walk, etc.

  4. â€˜Aâ€™ sometimes comes before determiners, for example, a few, a little, a lot of, a most, etc. but in the case of many, a or an - comes after. Few examples,

    • I have a few friends coming over.
    • There is a little milk in the jar.
    • Many a fan welcomed

  5. Article A/An is not used with uncountable nouns such as advice, accommodation, luggage, information, furniture, equipment, news, hair, etc. For example,

    • I gave him an advice. (remove an)
    • I bought a furniture for my house. (remove a)
    • Exception: There are some uncountable nouns that do not follow the rule given above, such as, noise, lie, etc. Eg: Do not make a noise.

Article â€“ The

*ï¸âƒ£ â€˜Theâ€™ is used when a reference is given in the sentence of the noun we are talking about. Eg: This is the book you have given me.

Rules:
  1. Before a superlative degree. For example,
    • Chetan is the best player in our team.
  2. To show uniqueness, oneness, union or something specific. For example,
    • The Ganga (the river Ganga);
    • The United States of America (America is a union of many states);
    • The Sun (there is only Sun in our solar system);
    • This is the child that was kidnapped the last Sunday.
  3. For using a proper noun as a common noun. For example,
    • He is the Virat Kohli of our team.
  4. Before adjectives when they represent the whole class. For example,
    • The young should respect the elder.
  5. For double comparison. For example,
    • The more you work the better your result will be.
    • The higher you go the lower will be the level of oxygen.
  6. To choose one out of two. For example,
    • He is the better of the two brothers.
  7. Before common nouns to make them abstract nouns. For example,
    • Let the judge in you decide who is guilty of the crime.
  8. Before language to denote nationality. For example,
    • The English defeated the French

Using â€˜theâ€™ with geographical nouns generally depends on the size and plurality of the things those nouns refer to. â€˜Theâ€™ is generally used everywhere except for some cases. So, itâ€™s better to know those exceptions first.

â€˜Theâ€™ must not precede:

  • Names of continents: Asia, Europe, Australia, Africa, South America, North America, Antarctica.
  • Names of countries: Australia, Bolivia, England, France, Spain, etc.
  • Names of states, cities, or towns: Los Angeles, Alaska, Sydney, London,
  • Names of streets: George street, Albion Street, New town street,
  • Names of singular lakes and bays: Lake Carey, Lake Eyre, Lake Hillier, Shark Bay,
  • Names of single mountains: Mount Everest, Mount Solitary, Mount Bindo, Mount Fuji, etc.
  • Names of single islands: Easter Island, Bare Island, Bird Island, Fatima Island,
  • Names of languages: Spanish, Russian, English, (When â€˜theâ€™ precedes these nouns, they re- fer to the population of those languages.)
  • Names of sports: cricket, football, basketball,
  • Names of discipline/subject of studies: biology, history, computer science, mathematics,

Note: â€˜Theâ€™ is a widely used article in English. Except for the list mentioned above and proper nouns, â€˜theâ€™ is used before almost all the nouns which mean something definite/particular. The above list has some opposite factors also. Those factors are explained in the following list.

â€˜Theâ€™ must precede:

  • Names of oceans, gulfs, seas, and rivers: the Pacific, the Atlantic, the Coral Sea, the Timor Sea, the Persian Gulf, the Nile, the Murray River, the Darling River, etc.
  • Names of countries with United States or islands: the United States of America (the USA), the UK, the UAE, the Philippines, etc.
  • Names of great lakes: the Great Lakes, the African Great Lakes
  • Names of mountain ranges: the Himalayas, the Alps, the Andes, etc.
  • Names of a group of Islands: the West Indies, the Andamans, etc.

Practice Questions ðŸ§ 

Directions: ðŸ’¡ Read the sentence to find out whether there is an error in it. The error, if any, will be in one part of the sentence. The number of that part is the answer. If there is no error, the answer is (5). Ignore errors of punctuation, if any.

Question 1:

A hourly rate of Rs.1000 is too much. (1)/ You’re turning education into a business. (2)/ We are supposed to help build these children into world leaders, (3)/ but most of them wouldn’t be able to afford this. (4)/ No error (5)

  • A) 1

  • B) 2

  • C) 3

  • D) 4

  • E) 5

Correct Option: A

Explanation:

  • The error is in (1). An should precede hourly, not A. Hence, Option A is the correct answer.

  • âœ… Correct Sentence: â€œAn hourly rate of Rs.1000 is too much. You’re turning education into a business. We are supposed to help build these children into world leaders, but most of them wouldn’t be able to afford this.â€

Question 2:

Owing to the emergence of several companies (1)/ such as, the Royal Sundaram, Bajaj Allianz, ICICI Lombard and HDFC in the field of healthcare (2)/, the popularity of health insurance in India(3)/ is on the rise (4)/. No error (5)

  • A) 1
  • B) 2
  • C) 3
  • D) 4
  • E) 5

Correct Option: B

Explanation:

  • No article is used before Proper Nouns, especially before the names of the companies.

  • âœ… The correct sentence will be â€œOwing to the emergence of several companies such as, Royal Sundaram, Bajaj Allianz, ICICI Lombard and HDFC in the field of healthcare, the popularity of health insurance in India is on the riseâ€.

Question 3:

Finally, poor corporate governance, (1)/ in a form of poor management of conflict of interest, inadequate understanding of key banking risks, (2)/ and poor oversight of the mechanisms for risk management and (3)/ internal audit result in risk management failures and financial instability. (4)/ No error (5)

  • A) 1
  • B) 2
  • C) 3
  • D) 4
  • E) 5

Correct Option: B

Explanation:

  • The article ‘a’ has been incorrectly used in the second part of the sentence. Since it points to a certain form of poor management it should be ’the’.

  • âœ… Correct sentence: ‘Finally, poor corporate governance, in the form of poor management of conflict of interest, inadequate understanding of key banking risks, (2) and poor oversight of the mechanisms for risk management and (3) internal audit result in risk management failures and financial instability.’

Question 4:

According to a 2010 Gallup poll, 4.4% of surveyed Mexicans, roughly 6.2 million (1)/ people, say that they would move permanently to the United States if given chance, (2)/ and according to the 2012 U.S. Global Leadership Report, 37% of (3)/ Mexicans approve of U.S. leadership, with 27% disapproving and 36% uncertain. (4)/ No error (5)

  • A) 1
  • B) 2
  • C) 3
  • D) 4
  • E) 5

Correct Option: B

Explanation:

The error lies in part 2 of the sentence where the article ’the’ or ‘a’ is needed before the word ‘chance’. Both can fit here. The sentence should read as: ‘…if given a chance’.. or ‘..if given the chance..’

Question 5:

Successive governments of different political (1)/ stripes on either side of the border came to comprehend that our (2)/ two nations played the unique role for each otherâ€™s (3)/ well-being that fed into the public narrative regarding the relationship. (4)/ No error (5)

  • A) 1
  • B) 2
  • C) 3
  • D) 4
  • E) 5

Correct Option: C

Explanation:

  • The error lies in part 3 of the sentence where the article ’the’ before the word ‘unique’ is wrong and needs to be replaced with the article ‘a’ to make the sentence correct. It is not something specific but ‘a role’ thus ’the’ is incorrect here. It should read as: ‘..played a unique role for..’

  • âœ… Correct sentence: “Successive governments of different political stripes on either side of the border came to comprehend that our two nations played a unique role for each otherâ€™s well-being that fed into the public narrative regarding the relationship”

item.title: Cloze Test
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

ðŸ“™ Rules for Cloze Test

Read Thoroughly

  • Read the passage provided very thoroughly to form an idea about the topic.
  • Read slowly and gain an understanding of the text.
  • Once the theme of the text is somewhat clear, your job becomes easier.
  • You can then go on to think of the appropriate words that suit the situation being described and proceed to filling in the blanks.

Link the Sentences Together

  • Remember that it is a passage with sentences that are connected to each other.
  • Do not make the mistake of treating each sentence like an individual one and filling in the blanks accordingly.
  • Try to come up with logical connections that link up the sentences together and your job will automatically become easier

The Type of Word to Fill in

  • Now look at the blanks carefully and assess the kind of words you have to fill in.
  • Which part of speech would it be? Would it be a noun, a pronoun, a verb, a preposition, a conjunction or an article?
For example:

  • A noun â€“ I forgot to carry my ______ to school. I therefore had to share with my friend. The logical answer here would be a book or tiffin.

  • An article â€“ He ate ______ papaya and threw________ seeds away. Articles are usually the easiest to answer. Fill in â€˜aâ€™ and â€˜anâ€™ where talking about general facts and â€˜theâ€™ when using it before something specific.

Here, the âœ… answer is â€˜theâ€™ or â€˜hisâ€™ in the first case and â€˜theâ€™ or â€˜itsâ€™ in the second.

  • A verb â€“ ________for half an hour left me breathless. The idea of being breathless connotes something strenuous like â€˜exercisingâ€™ or â€˜runningâ€™. In this way, think of the appropriate word to fill in.

Eliminate Options

  • We can easily identify most unfit/illogical words in answer options.
  • We should quickly eliminate these words. Only after that we should try to most fit word.

Elimination will enhance accuracy and hence score.

Go with Frequently Used Words

*ï¸âƒ£ Sometimes, you may not be able to decide between two words. In this case, if you see a word in the options that is frequently used with the words around the blank, then pick that option.

For example

Q1. Can I have a _______ word with you?

A. Swift

B. Quick

C. Prompt

ðŸ«µ You can see ðŸ‘€ that the three options nearly mean the same thing. How do you decide which one fits the blank?

Sometimes in English, some words are used more frequently with some others. Like â€˜bad habitâ€™, â€˜hardly everâ€™, â€˜happy endingâ€™, â€˜take a seatâ€™, â€˜make roomâ€™ etc. In the same way, the words â€˜quickâ€™ and â€˜wordâ€™ are used together frequently. So â€˜quickâ€™ should be your answer in this case.

Check Tone of Passage

  • The passage is usually written in a certain tone; sometimes narrative, sometimes critical, sometimes humorous.
  • Pick words that fit in with the tone of the passage.
For example:

Q1. Jonah _______ down the stairs, bumping along like a quarter in a tumbling dryer.

ðŸŸ¨ A. tumbled

ðŸŸ¨ B. fell

ðŸŸ¨ C. dropped


Clearly, you can use either â€˜tumbledâ€™ or â€˜fellâ€™ in this blank. But the rest of the sentence is written in a humorous vein. So we try to maintain the tone of the sentence. This is best accomplished by the use of the word â€˜tumbledâ€™ as it brings to mind images of people falling funnily.

Practice More ðŸ’ª

  • In the end, there is no substitute for hard work and practice.
  • Try to complete three to four passages each day while preparing and get an insight into your problem areas.
  • Work on them and go deliver your best
Helpful Hints ðŸ’¡
#1 You must ensure that the word you have inserted in the blank enables you to read the sentence smoothly and correctly
#2 Apply grammar rules (grammar rules â€“ prepositions, noun, pronoun, adj, verb etc)
  • Preposition following a noun, adjective or verb. (Example: look at images)
  • A prepositional phrase. (Example: in spite of )
  • An adverb. (Example: they vacated the house two years ago)
  • A connector. (Example: it is raining, therefore ground is wet.)
  • A conjunction. (Example: although he is seven, he can speak eight languages)
  • A auxiliary verb, an article, a pronoun , either subject or object. (example : it is easier to know)
  • A comparative or superlative involved? (Example: sheâ€™s taller than me)

Previous Year Questions ðŸ™‹â€â™‚ï¸

Directions: ðŸ’¡ In the following passage there are blanks, each of which has been numbered. These numbers are printed below the passage and against each, five words are suggested, one of which fits the blank appropriately. Find out the appropriate word in each case.

Practice Set 1 ðŸ§ 

Actually every day we all are engaged in this business of reading people. We do it (1). We want to figure others out. So, we (2) make guesses about what others think, value, want and feel and we do so based on our (3) beliefs and understandings about human nature. We do so because if we can figure out (4) and intentions of others the possibility of them (5) or hurting us, (6) and this will help us to (7) a lot of unnecessary pain and trouble. We also make second guesses about what they will do in future, how they will (8) if we make this or that response. We do all this second guessing based upon our (9) of what we believe about the persons inner nature 10) his or her roles and, manners. We mind read their fill (11) their motives. Also, every day we mis-guess and misread. Why? Because of the complexity, (12), and multidimensional functioning of people. After all how well do you read your own thoughts, aims, values, motives, beliefs etc.? How well do you know your own structuring process your own thinking and (13) styles?
