item.title: Conjunctions
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

ðŸ“™ What are Conjunctions?

  • ðŸ‘‰ Conjunctions are words that link other words, phrases, or clauses together. For example,
  • ðŸ‘‰ I like cooking and eating, but I donâ€™t like washing dishes afterward.
  • ðŸ‘‰ Sophie is clearly exhausted, yet she insists on dancing till dawn.
  • ðŸ‘‰ Conjunctions allow you to form complex, elegant sentences and avoid the choppiness of multiple short sentences.
  • ðŸ‘‰ Make sure that the phrases joined by conjunctions are parallel (share the same structure.)
Incorrect ðŸš« I work quickly and am careful.
Correct âœ… I work quickly and carefully.

Coordinating Conjunctions

  • ðŸŸ¨ Coordinating conjunctions allow you to join words, phrases, and clauses of equal grammatical rank in a sentence.
  • ðŸŸ¨ The most common coordinating conjunctions are: for, and, nor, but, or, yet, and so;
  • ðŸŸ¨ An easy way to remember these, is by using the mnemonic device, â€œFANBOYS".
F OR
A ND
N OR
B UT
O R
Y ET
S O
Examples:
no. examples
1 Iâ€™d like pizza or a salad for lunch.
2 We needed a place to concentrate, so we packed up our things and went to the library.
3 Jesse didnâ€™t have much money, but she got by.

Note: ðŸ‘€ Notice the use of the comma when a coordinating conjunction is joining two independent clauses.

Correlative Conjunctions

  • ðŸŸ§ Correlative conjunctions are pairs of conjunctions that work together.
  • ðŸŸ§ Some examples are: either/or, neither/nor, and not only/but also.
Example:
no. examples
1 Not only am I finished studying for English, but Iâ€™m also finished writing my history essay.
2 I am finished with both my English essay and my history essay.

Subordinating Conjunctions

  • ðŸŸ¦ Subordinating conjunctions join independent and dependent clauses.
  • ðŸŸ¦ A subordinating conjunction can signal a cause-and-effect relationship, a contrast, or some other kind of relationship between the clauses.
  • ðŸŸ¦ Common subordinating conjunctions are:
Because As Though Whereas
Since Although While
  • ðŸŸ¦ Sometimes an adverb can function as a conjunction, such as:
    • Until
    • After
    • Before
Example:
1 I can stay out until the clock strikes twelve.
- Exaplanation: Here, the adverb until functions as a coordinating conjunction to connect two ideas: I can stay out (the independent clause) and the clock strikes twelve (the dependent clause).

Note: ðŸ‘€ The independent clause could stand alone as a sentence; the dependent clause depends on the independent clause to make sense.

  • The subordinating conjunction doesnâ€™t need to go in the middle of the sentence.
  • It has to be part of the dependent clause, but the dependent clause can come before the independent clause.
  • The subordinating conjunction doesnâ€™t need to go in the middle of the sentence.
  • It has to be part of the dependent clause, but the dependent clause can come before the independent clause.
Example:
1 Before he leaves, make sure his room is clean.

*ï¸âƒ£ If the dependent clause comes first, use a comma before the independent clause.

Example:
1 I drank a glass of water because I was thirsty. (independent clause 1st)
2 Because I was thirsty, I drank a glass of water. (dependent clause 1st)

Rules for Using a Coordinating Conjunction

âš¡Rule #1

  • Put a comma before the coordinating conjunction when it is used to connect two independent clauses.
  • A clause is a group of words that contain a subject and a verb.
  • An independent clause (or main clause) expresses a complete thought. It can stand alone as a sentence.
Example:
1 I like apples.

âš¡A dependent clause does not express a complete thought. It cannot stand alone as a sentence.

Example:
1 â€œthat I saw last month.â€
Example of Independent Clauses:
1 Tom walked the dog.
Explanation: It is an independent clause Subject: Tom Verb: walked
2 Tom grabbed the mail.
Explanation: It is an independent clause Subject: Tom Verb: grabbed

âš¡These two independent clauses can be combined with a coordinating conjunction. When we combine these two sentences, the second “Tom” will be changed to “he.”
1 Tom walked the dog.
Explanation: It is an independent clause Subject: Tom Verb: walked
2 Tom grabbed the mail.
Explanation: It is an independent clause Subject: Tom Verb: grabbed
Here are a few more examples of coordinating conjunctions connecting independent clauses.
Incorrect ðŸš« I want to go see a movie but my sister has my car.
Correct âœ… I want to go see a movie, but my sister has my car.
Incorrect ðŸš« Lisa loves cats yet she does not want one living in her house.
Correct âœ… Lisa loves cats, yet she does not want one living in her house.

âš¡Rule #2

  • When using a coordinating conjunction to connect two items, do not use a comma.
  • In the example above with Tom and his dog, we can leave out the comma if we do not have two independent clauses.
  • We do this by leaving out the subject in the second part of the sentence (he).
1 Tom walked the dog and grabbed the mail.
Explanation: “Tom walked the dog” is an independent clause, but “grabbed the mail” is not.
Here are a few more examples of how to use a coordinating conjunction to connect two items that are not independent clauses.
Incorrect ðŸš« She likes apples, and bananas.
Correct âœ… She likes apples and bananas.
Incorrect ðŸš« My brother is young, but smart.
Correct âœ… My brother is young but smart.

âš¡Rule #3

  • When using a coordinating conjunction with a list of items (three or more in number), the comma before the coordinating conjunction is optional.
  • You should put or leave out the comma before the coordinating conjunction based on the style guide you are using.
Example with a comma:
1 She is cooking chicken, potatoes, corn, and carrot. OR She is cooking chicken, potatoes, corn and carrot.

Conjunctions List ðŸ“ƒ

  • ðŸ‘‰ There are only a few common conjunctions, yet these words perform many functions.
  • ðŸ‘‰ They present explanations, ideas, exceptions, consequences, and contrasts.
Here is a list of conjunctions commonly used in English:
  • And
  • For
  • Neither
  • So
  • As
  • Just
  • Nor
  • Whether
  • Because
  • Or
  • Not only
  • Yet
  • But

How to Use Conjunctions ðŸ§ 

âš¡Lest â€“ Should
  • Lest _________ should
  • “Not” is included in the word “lest”.
  • It has negativity in itself so we canâ€™t use “not” with this word in a sentence.
Examples:
Incorrect ðŸš« I was afraid to open the door lest he would follow me.
Correct âœ… I was afraid to open the door lest he should follow me.
Incorrect ðŸš« Work hard lest you should not fail.
Correct âœ… Work hard lest you should fail.
âš¡So â€“ As
  • So ________ as
  • It shows negativity in a sentence.
  • We use these words to show negativity.
Examples:
Incorrect ðŸš« She is not so intelligent as I.
Correct âœ… She is not as intelligent as I.
Incorrect ðŸš« Nothing is so good as we think.
Correct âœ… Nothing is as good as we think.
âš¡As - as
  • As __________ as
  • It shows positivity in a sentence.
Examples:
Incorrect ðŸš« She looks so beautiful as a princess.
Correct âœ… She looks as beautiful as a princess.
Incorrect ðŸš« She is so tall as her mother.
Correct âœ… She is as tall as her mother.
âš¡Other - Than
  • Other ________ Than
  • Sometimes in an exam, we can see “other” with “but” in a sentence, ignore this without thinking and instead use â€œthanâ€.
Examples:
Incorrect ðŸš« The form cannot be signed by anyone than other you.
Correct âœ… The form cannot be signed by anyone other than you.
Incorrect ðŸš« Iâ€™m not aware of anything after that, than other trying to get an ambulance.
Correct âœ… I’m not aware of anything after that, other than trying to get an ambulance.
âš¡Either - or/ Neither - nor/ Not only - but also
  • Either __________ or
  • Neither _________no
  • Not only ________but also
  • There can be three types of error in these conjunctions for instance. We can trace certain common errors in the aforementioned conjunctions.
We canâ€™t use either with nor and neither with or. For example:
Incorrect ðŸš« Either you nor your brother has won the prize.
Correct âœ… Either you or your brother has won the prize.
Incorrect ðŸš« Neither he or his brother can walk faster than I.
Correct âœ… Neither he nor his brother can walk faster than I. (âˆš)
These words are always used with uncommon part of the sentence. For example:
Incorrect ðŸš« Cars is not only economical, but convenient.
Correct âœ… Cars are not only economical, but also convenient.
Incorrect ðŸš« Should I either buy red sweater or blue?
Correct âœ… Should I buy either the red sweater or the blue sweater?

Verbs According to the First Subject

Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« Unfortunately neither nor red sweater blue sweater is available.
Correct âœ… Unfortunately, neither the red sweater nor the blue sweater are currently available.

âš¡As long as/With/Along with/Together

  • When we add two subjects with these words, then we need to focus on the form of verb because in these types of sentences we should use verb according to the first subject
Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« I will lend my camera, if you use as long as carefully.
Correct âœ… I will lend you my camera as long as youâ€™re careful when using it.
Incorrect ðŸš« I buy a Happy Meal with free toy.
Correct âœ… I buy a Happy Meal because it comes with a free toy.

Else â€“ but

  • Else ________ but
  • These words have negative meaning. The only auxiliary verb that can follow “else” is but.
Example:
Correct âœ… You do nothing else but complain.

Whether - or

  • Whether _________or
  • Whether is always followed by “or” in a sentence and we canâ€™t use “that” before whether.
Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« I buy a Happy Meal with free toy.
Correct âœ… I buy a Happy Meal because it comes with a free toy.
Incorrect ðŸš« I asked her that whether her father was at home.
Correct âœ… I asked her whether her father was at home.

As if/as though

  • Meaning: (Subject+v1+as if/as though + subject + were+â€¦..)
  • We use as if and as though to make comparisons. They have a similar meaning.
  • We use as if and as though to talk about an imaginary situation or a situation that may not be true but that is likely or possible. As if is more common than as though.
Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« He acts as if he is a prince.
Correct âœ… He acts as if he were a prince.
Incorrect ðŸš« She felt a pain like a knife had pierced her heart.
Correct âœ… She felt a pain as though a knife had pierced her heart.

The reason/whyâ€¦that

  • After the reason/the reason why we must use “that” in a sentence because sometimes we can see “due to, because, on account of” etc. after the reason/the reason why.
Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« The reason why I donâ€™t include pineapple in my diet is an allergy.
Correct âœ… The reason why I donâ€™t include pineapples in my diet is due to an allergy.
Incorrect ðŸš« The reason for the bus being late was because the bus was involved in an accident.
Correct âœ… The reason for the bus being late was that the bus was involved in an accident.

Unless

  • It is used as a conjunction in the meaning of (if not) â€“ condition/situation.
  • Until: it used for time.
  • These words have negativity in themselves so we canâ€™t use “not” with them.
Example:
Incorrect ðŸš« Unless she does not mend her behaviour, I shall send her out.
Correct âœ… Unless she mends her behaviour, she is not allowed to go out.
Incorrect ðŸš« Until I do not inform my father I shall not go out of my house.
Correct âœ… I shall not go out of my house until I inform my father.

item.title: DIrect and Indirect Speech
item.description:
The voice of a verb indicates whether the subject of the sentence performs the action or receives the action. There are two main voices in English: active and passive.

What is Direct & Indirect Speech? ðŸ¤·â€â™‚ï¸

  • Direct speech - reporting the message of the speaker in exact words as spoken by him.
  • Direct speech example: Rama said â€˜I am busy nowâ€™.
  • Indirect speech: reporting the message of the speaker in our own words
  • Indirect speech example: Rama said that he was very busy then.

Direct and Indirect Speech Rules

ðŸ‘‰ To change a sentence of direct speech into indirect speech there are various factors that are considered such as reporting verbs, modals, time, place, pronoun, tense, etc. we will take up all the factors one by one.

Rule #1 - Direct to Indirect Speech Conversion - Reporting Verb

  1. When the reporting verb of direct speech is in past tense then all the present tenses are changed to corresponding past tense in indirect speech.

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: she said, â€œI am happy.â€
  • Indirect: She said (that) she was happy.
  1. In indirect speech tenses do not change if the words used within the quotes (â€œ â€) talk of a habitual action or universal truth.

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: He said, â€œwe cannot live without air.â€
  • Indirect: He said that we cannot live without air.
  1. The tenses of direct speech do not change if the reporting verb is in future tense or present tense.

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: She says/will say, â€œshe is going.â€
  • Indirect: She says/will say she is going.

Rule #2 - Direct Speech to Indirect Speech conversion - Present Tense

  1. Present Perfect Changes to Past Perfect.

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: â€œI have been to Bostonâ€, She told me.
  • Indirect: She told me that she had been to Boston.
  1. Present Continuous Changes to Past Continuous

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: â€œI am playing the guitarâ€, she explained.
  • Indirect: She explained that she was playing the guitar.
  1. Present Perfect Changes to Past Perfect

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: He said, â€œshe has finished her homeworkâ€.
  • Indirect: He said that she had finished her homework.
  1. Simple Present Changes to Simple Past

Direct to indirect speech example:

  • Direct: â€œI am unwellâ€, she said.
  • Indirect: She said that she was unwell.

Rule #3 - Direct Speech to Indirect Speech conversion - Past Tense & Future Tense

Practice Questions: ðŸ§ 

Directions: ðŸ’¡ Given below are questions sentences in Direct/Indirect Speech along with four options. You are required to read the Direct and Indirect Speech questions carefully and select the option that expresses the same sentence in the reverse speech i.e., Indirect/Direct Speech:

Q1. The designer said to her, â€œwill you have the dress ready by tomorrow evening?â€

ðŸŸ¨ 1. The designer asked her if she would have the dress ready by next evening.

ðŸŸ¨ 2. The designer asked her that she would have the dress ready by next evening.

ðŸŸ¨ 3. The designer asked her that if she will like to have the dress by next evening.

ðŸŸ¨ 4. The designer asked her that she will have the suit ready by next evening.

âœ… Answer: 1

item.title: One Word Substitution
item.description:
One Word Substitution: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ“âœ¨

What is One Word Substitution? ðŸ¤”

  • Using a single word to replace a lengthy phrase, making sentences clearer and shorter.
  • Example: â€œA person who can use both hands with easeâ€ â†’ Ambidextrous âœ‹ðŸ¤š

Categories of One Word Substitution ðŸ“š

  • Generic Terms ðŸ·ï¸
  • Government/Systems ðŸ›ï¸
  • Venue/Spots ðŸŸï¸
  • Group/Collection ðŸ‘¥
  • People/Person ðŸ§‘â€ðŸ¤â€ðŸ§‘
  • Murder/Death âš°ï¸
  • Profession/Research ðŸ‘©â€ðŸ”¬
  • Sound ðŸ”Š

Important Examples with Emojis

  • Infallible: Incapable of making mistakes âœ…
  • Inevitable: Certain to happen â˜‘ï¸
  • Nostalgia: Longing for the past ðŸ•°ï¸
  • Panacea: Remedy for all problems ðŸ’Š
  • Pedantic: Too concerned with rules ðŸ“
  • Plagiarism: Copying someoneâ€™s work ðŸ“

item.title: Preposition
item.description:
Prepositions: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ“ðŸ—ºï¸

What is a Preposition? ðŸ¤”

  • A preposition shows the relationship (in space, time, or logic) between two or more people, places, or things.
  • Usually followed by a noun or pronoun.
    • Example: The cat is on the table. ðŸˆðŸª‘

Common Prepositions & Their Uses with Examples and Emojis

1. On

  • Surface: The book is on the table. ðŸ“šðŸª‘
  • Days/Dates: I will come on Monday. ðŸ“…
  • Devices: She is on the phone. ðŸ“±
  • Body Parts: Ring on my finger. ðŸ’
  • State: The products are on sale. ðŸ·ï¸

2. At

  • Place: Meet me at the park. ðŸŒ³
  • Time: See you at 5 p.m. â°
  • Activity: John laughed at my acting. ðŸ˜‚
  • Email: Contact me at xyz@xyz.com ðŸ“§

3. In

  • Location: I live in Mumbai. ðŸ™ï¸
  • Time (months, years, seasons): School starts in March. ðŸ“†
  • Feeling/Opinion: I believe in hard work. ðŸ’ª
  • Size/Color/Shape: The dress comes in four sizes. ðŸ‘—

4. To

  • Destination: Going to college. ðŸ«
  • Relationship: Your answer is important to me. ðŸ¤
  • Limit: Piled up to the roof. ðŸ 
  • Period: I am here from 10 to 5. â³

5. Of

  • Belonging: Dreamed of being famous. ðŸŒŸ
  • Reference: Picture of my birthday. ðŸŽ‚
  • Amount: A group of people. ðŸ‘¥

6. For

  • Reason: I am happy for you. ðŸ˜Š
  • Duration: Stayed for one year. ðŸ“…
  • Use: Preparing for exams. ðŸ“

Other Important Prepositions with Examples

Preposition Meaning/Use Example Sentence Emoji
above higher than/over The sun is above the clouds. â˜€ï¸â˜ï¸
across from one side to another Ran across the road. ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸ðŸ›£ï¸
after following/later than I’ll call you after lunch. ðŸ“žðŸ½ï¸
against in opposition/contact Sofa is against the wall. ðŸ›‹ï¸ðŸ§±
along from end to end Walking along the street. ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸ðŸ™ï¸
among surrounded by Peter was among the spectators. ðŸ‘¦ðŸ‘¥
around in a circle/near Walked around the table. ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸ðŸª‘
before earlier/in front of The day before yesterday. ðŸ“…
behind at the back of Passengers sit behind the driver. ðŸ§‘â€âœˆï¸ðŸš—
below lower than Shorts are below his knees. ðŸ©³ðŸ¦µ
beneath under Pen was beneath the books. ðŸ–Šï¸ðŸ“š
beside next to Bank is beside the cinema. ðŸ¦ðŸŽ¬
between separating two things Sat between Tom and Jane. ðŸ‘©ðŸ‘¦ðŸ‘©
by near/not later than Report by Friday. ðŸ“„ðŸ“†
inside on the inner part Bird is inside the cage. ðŸ¦ðŸ•Šï¸
into enter a closed space Went into the shop. ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸ðŸª
near/close to close to School is near the church. ðŸ«â›ª
off down/away from Fell off the horse. ðŸ‡â¬‡ï¸
on touching a surface Plate is on the table. ðŸ½ï¸ðŸª‘
onto move to a surface Cat jumped onto the roof. ðŸˆðŸ 
opposite facing Sat opposite Tom. ðŸ‘©ðŸ‘¦ðŸ‘©
out of move from a closed space Got out of the taxi. ðŸš•ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸
outside on the outer side Garden is outside the house. ðŸ¡ðŸŒ³
over above/across Plane flew over the Atlantic. âœˆï¸ðŸŒŠ
past beyond Drove past the supermarket. ðŸš—ðŸª
through from one side to other Seine flows through Paris. ðŸŒŠðŸ™ï¸
under beneath/below Water flows under the bridge. ðŸ’§ðŸŒ‰
up towards a higher position Walked up the stairs. ðŸš¶â€â™‚ï¸â¬†ï¸
within inside Live within the old city. ðŸ™ï¸
without not have/lack Coffee without milk. â˜•ðŸ¥›âŒ

Prepositions in Abstract Meanings ðŸ’¡

  • Prepositions can show not just physical space, but also ideas:
    • “He is behind the government.” (supports)
    • “Learning Chinese in a year was beyond them.” (too difficult)

Prepositions After Adjectives & Nouns ðŸ§©

Adjective/Noun Preposition Example Emoji
aware, full of She is full of energy. âš¡
different, separate from This is different from that. ðŸ”„
similar, due to This is similar to mine. ðŸ‘¯â€â™‚ï¸
familiar, wrong with Iâ€™m familiar with this. ðŸ¤
good, surprised at Good at singing. ðŸŽ¤
interested in Interested in music. ðŸŽµ
responsible, good for Responsible for the project. ðŸ—ï¸
worried, excited about Excited about the trip. âœˆï¸

Prepositions After Verbs (Phrasal Verbs) ðŸ”—

  • Look for (search): I am looking for my keys. ðŸ—ï¸
  • Wait for (stay until): Wait for the bus. ðŸšŒ
  • Accuse of: He accused her of cheating. ðŸš¨

When to Omit Prepositions ðŸš«

  • No preposition before time/place words with qualifiers (this, that, next, last, every, all, before):
    • She went this morning.
    • Met him last Sunday.
    • See you next week.
  • No preposition before: yesterday, today, tomorrow:
    • He will come tomorrow.
    • I met him yesterday.
  • No preposition before “home”:
    • I am going home. ðŸ¡

Common Mistakes & Quick Fixes âŒâœ…

  • Arrive at (place), Arrive in (city/country):
    • Arrived at the station. ðŸš‰
    • Arrived in London. ðŸ™ï¸
  • At night, in the morning/afternoon/evening:
    • Mumbai is beautiful at night. ðŸŒƒ
    • I study in the morning. ðŸŒ…
  • For (period), Since (point in time):
    • Iâ€™ve lived here for five years.
    • Iâ€™ve lived here since 2020.
  • Live/work/study in (city/country), at (address):
    • Live in Delhi. ðŸ™ï¸
    • Live at 34 Brown Street. ðŸ 
  • Welcome to (place):
    • Welcome to India! ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³
  • Married to (someone):
    • She is married to John. ðŸ’

Practice Questions ðŸ“

  1. Peter is playing tennis ___ Sunday. Answer: on
  2. My brother’s birthday is ___ the 5th of November. Answer: on
  3. My birthday is ___ May. Answer: in
  4. We are going to see my parents ___ the weekend. Answer: at
  5. ___ 1666, a great fire broke out in London. Answer: In
  6. I don’t like walking alone in the streets ___ night. Answer: at
  7. What are you doing ___ the afternoon? Answer: in
  8. My friend has been living in Canada ___ two years. Answer: for

Quick Reference Table ðŸ“Š

Preposition Use/Example Emoji
on on Monday, on the table ðŸ“…ðŸª‘
in in May, in Mumbai ðŸ“†ðŸ™ï¸
at at 5 p.m., at the park â°ðŸŒ³
for for two years ðŸ•°ï¸
since since 2020 ðŸ“…
to to the station ðŸš‰
of picture of my birthday ðŸŽ‚

Tip:

  • Use prepositions to show time, place, direction, and relationships.
  • Remember common patterns and avoid typical mistakes!
  • Practice with examples and emojis for quick recall! ðŸ˜ƒ123

item.title: Reading Comprehension
item.description:
Reading Comprehension: Study Material Made Easy with Emojis ðŸ“–ðŸ§

What is Reading Comprehension? ðŸ¤”

  • A test of your focus, patience, understanding, and analysis skills.
  • One of the most scoring topics in English exams!
  • Youâ€™ll encounter different types of passages and questions that check your ability to find information, infer meaning, and think critically12.

Types of Passages Youâ€™ll See ðŸ“š

  1. Descriptive Passages
    • Long, mostly data-driven.
    • Direct questionsâ€”just find the facts!
    • Tip: Note important points to avoid scrolling up and down. ðŸ“
  2. Analytical Passages
    • Analyze theories (scientific, political, etc.).
    • Can be tricky and a bit boring if youâ€™re not an avid reader.
    • Focus on the main idea and key points. ðŸ’¡
  3. Hypothetical Passages
    • Usually short, abstract, or fantasy-based.
    • Can be hard to decode the main idea.
    • Tip: Donâ€™t get biasedâ€”just follow the authorâ€™s logic, no matter how strange! ðŸ¦„

How to Tackle Reading Comprehension? ðŸ›¡ï¸

  • Read a Variety: Start reading different things (editorials, articles, stories) to get used to different styles. ðŸ“°ðŸ“š
  • Attempt Wholeheartedly: Donâ€™t skip or rush. Take your time and build up speed gradually. ðŸƒâ€â™‚ï¸
  • Skip Wisely: If you canâ€™t get the main idea, skip inference-based questions to avoid negative marking. ðŸš«
  • Note Data: For data-driven questions, jot down main points for quick reference. ðŸ—’ï¸
  • Practice Daily: Aim for 3â€“4 passages a day. Mastery comes with regular practice! ðŸ“†

Tips for Exam Success ðŸŽ¯

  • Donâ€™t Panic: Long passages are often straightforward.
  • Frame the Main Idea: For analytical passages, focus on the core message.
  • Believe the Author: For hypothetical ones, accept the authorâ€™s worldâ€”even if itâ€™s bizarre!
  • Be Cautious: Donâ€™t let your opinions interfere with understanding the passage.

Sample Question Types & How to Approach Them ðŸ“

  • Main Idea: Whatâ€™s the passage mostly about? Look for the overall theme, not just details!
  • Inference: What can you guess from whatâ€™s said? Read between the lines!
  • Vocabulary: What does a word mean in context? Check the sentence and nearby clues!
  • Fact-based: What does the passage directly state? Find the exact line in the passage!

Example: Social Networking & Security ðŸ‘¤ðŸ”’

  • Main Idea: Importance of security in social networking.
  • Threats: Identity theft, hacking, overconfidence in security.
  • Precautions: Strong passwords, careful with status updates, avoid sharing travel plans, donâ€™t click unknown links.
  • Burglars: Love constant updates about your movements!
  • Biggest Threat: Overconfidence.
  • Tip: Never assume youâ€™re â€œtoo safeâ€ online!

Example: Nationalism in China ðŸ‡¨ðŸ‡³

  • Main Idea: Nationalism as a weapon in diplomacy.
  • Effect: Economic boycotts, protests, business losses.
  • Presidentâ€™s Concern: Protests shouldnâ€™t backfire on leadership.
  • Objective: Pressure Korea to reconsider its US missile deal.
  • Vocabulary:
    • Wary = cautious; opposite: careless.
    • Make it hurt = cause serious problems.

Example: Online Grocery Market in India ðŸ›’ðŸ‡®ðŸ‡³

  • Main Idea: Growth and advantages of online groceries.
  • Key Points:
    • 60% of retail market is groceries (everyone needs food!).
    • Started in 2011; rapid growth due to internet, convenience, discounts.
    • Big Basket and Zopnow are major players.
    • Online groceries offer more variety and hassle-free shopping than traditional stores.
    • Investments from venture capitalists due to high growth potential.
  • Vocabulary:
    • Comprehensive = complete.
    • Commendable = deserving praise.

Quick Reference Table ðŸ“Š

Passage Type What To Do Emoji
Descriptive Note key data, answer directly ðŸ“Š
Analytical Find main idea, focus on logic ðŸ’¡
Hypothetical Accept authorâ€™s view, donâ€™t judge ðŸ¦„

Pro Tips for RC Success ðŸ’¡

  • Underline or jot down key points as you read.
  • Donâ€™t let tough vocabulary slow you downâ€”use context clues!
  • Practice, practice, practice!

Keep these strategies and tips in mind, and youâ€™ll master Reading Comprehension with confidence and a smile! ðŸ˜ƒðŸ“–12
